organic_results.title: White flight and white return in Norfolk: A test of predictions
organic_results.snippet: Predictions in 1981 that the flight of white students from the public schools in Norfolk, Virginia, would resegregate the public schools unless busing was stopped led the federal courts to order the end of busing in Grades K-5 in 1986. The authors' research shows that these predictions were incorrect. After 1982, white flight nearly stopped in Grades K-12 and reversed in Grades K-5. Since busing ended, the rate of return of white students to public schools has been about one-third of what was predicted, and parents' attitudes toward the …

publication_info.summary: LG Carr, DJ Zeigler - Sociology of Education, 1990 - JSTOR

organic_results.title: Response to Carr and Zeigler's" White Flight and White Return in Norfolk"
organic_results.snippet: As Caff and Zeigler (1990) stated in their critique of my 1982 study of white flight and white return in Norfolk, my analysis and predictions assumed that mandatory busing would end in all grades by fall 1982. Although the Norfolk School Board voted to end busing in 1983, it did so only for elementary grades K-5 and, because of court actions and appeals, that policy was not implemented until fall 1986. But Carr and Zeigler reach their conclusions that" in practically every respect, Armor's predictions... were in error" only by omitting key portions of …
